title: 48 days in the 'swamp' of the Pelicot rape trial: What Le Monde's court reporters saw
summary: Our court reporters Henri Seckel and Pascale Robert-Diard recount 48 days of big-screen videos, sordid details and failed apologies: 'Every day, we thought we'd seen and heard the worst. But the worst was worse the next day.'

title: 'The arrival of North Korean troops and Trump's election have shifted the balance in Ukraine'
summary: The war in Europe is encountering two turning points on the international scene. Paradoxically, Volodymyr Zelensky and Donald Trump converge on one concept: 'peace through strength,' explains Le Monde's Sylvie Kauffmann in her column.

title: Hezbollah says Israel 'cannot impose conditions' for truce
summary: Israeli Foreign Minister Gideon Saar, meanwhile, said any ceasefire deal must ensure Israel still has the 'freedom to act' against Hezbollah. Hezbollah began its cross-border attacks in support of its ally Hamas following the Palestinian group's assault on Israel on October 7, 2023, which sparked the war in Gaza.

title: Republicans on the House Ethics Committee reject releasing report on Matt Gaetz
summary: Gaetz has launched an effort to secure his nomination, meeting behind closed doors with Republican senators about the sexual misconduct allegations against him. When the new Congress convenes on January 3, 2025, senators are expected to begin holding hearings on Trump's nominees, with voting possible on Inauguration Day, January 20.

title: Seen on TV: Donald Trump's decisive recruitment criterion
summary: To be in charge of Medicare and Medicaid, the president-elect has nominated Mehmet Oz, known for promoting improbable remedies on TV. The Department of Education, meanwhile, will be headed by Linda McMahon, former CEO of the powerful wrestling federation WWE.

title: Thieves steal artifacts from Paris museum
summary: The culprits struck around 10:30 am at the Cognacq-Jay museum in the touristy Marais district of central Paris and made off with 'five historic boxes and snuffboxes' that were on display as part of an exhibition titled 'Luxe de poche' ('Pocket Luxury').

title: Hezbollah beeper attacks: Legal risks for Netanyahu
summary: The prime minister's acknowledgment of the attacks committed in mid-September against the Lebanese Shiite movement exposes him to prosecution before national and international courts.

title: Tennessee man involved in US Capitol riot is convicted of planning to kill investigators
summary: Edward Kelley, 35, was one of hundreds of rioters arrested on charges of illegally entering the US Capitol. While awaiting trial, Kelley developed a plan to kill law enforcement, including FBI agents, prosecutors said. He faces up to life in prison at sentencing in May.

title: Trump appoints loyalist Matt Whitaker as NATO ambassador
summary: Donald Trump said he had chosen former attorney general Matt Whitaker to serve as US ambassador to NATO, the bedrock Western alliance that the president-elect has repeatedly expressed skepticism about.

title: The dangerous liaison between inflation and populism
summary: From the Roman Empire to the United States, inflation has provoked anger and sometimes regime change.

title: Biden authorizes Ukraine to use antipersonnel landmines against Russians
summary: US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said the shift in policy follows changing tactics by the Russians.

title: French farmers lift border blockade
summary: After discussions with Prime Minister Michel Barnier, hard-line farmers' union Coordination Rurale lifted its roadblock for heavy trucks on the A9 motorway, which links southwestern France with Spain's northeast, police said.

title: At least 150 people killed in Port-au-Prince in past week, says UN
summary: The latest intensification of violence in the Haitian capital has brought the total number of deaths in Haiti this year to over 4,500, the United Nations said Wednesday.

title: Two complaints filed in Algeria over prize-winning French novel
summary: The survivor of a 1990s massacre has alleged that the main character in Kamel Daoud's prize-winning book 'Houris' is based on her experiences.

title: At the G20 in Rio, the great rift between the West and the Global South led by China
summary: Brazil's President Lula was keen to avoid controversial issues such as the war in Ukraine. But this subject did interrupt the summit, as Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov was invited to attend on the sidelines.

title: At the trial of Le Pen and her party, the other accused are hardly defended
summary: The far-right Rassemblement National's lawyers are intent on getting Marine Le Pen through the embezzlement trial unscathed, even if it means collateral damage.

title: SpaceX fails to repeat Starship booster catch as Trump looks on
summary: Donald Trump joined SpaceX founder/CEO Elon Musk to witness the mega-rocket's latest test flight on Tuesday, but the President-elect didn't get to see the engineering marvel demonstrated last month. It made a more subdued splashdown in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: In the US, 'the Democratic administration's betrayal squandered some of the capital it had built up with unions'
summary: Philippe Askenazy writes in his column that the Biden administration lost the support of workers, when it decided to block an emblematic strike by American railroad workers in 2022.

title: Mali junta chief sacks PM and government
summary: Prime Minister Choguel Kokalla Maiga, 66, previously served as a minister on several occasions and ran three times as a presidential candidate. He was the civilian face of the junta's strategic pivot away from former colonial ruler France and toward closer political and military ties with Russia.

title: Boris Johnson's 'Unleashed': Self-mockery from a man in power
summary: From his tussle with the president of the Supreme Court to the 'Partygate' scandal during the pandemic, the shaggy-haired ex-British prime minister tells his side of the story, peppered with anecdotes and incongruous details.

title: Will France have a government at Christmas?
summary: As Prime Minister Michel Barnier prepares to activate Article 49.3 to pass his budget bill without a vote, eyes are turning to the far right. Will Marine Le Pen's party join the left in backing a motion of no confidence to topple the government?

title: Five Parisian addresses with a Mexican twist
summary: In Paris, a selection of five restaurants will take you on a gastronomic flight to Mexico, where you can enjoy octopus with burnt chili in a traditional establishment, monkfish with mezcal in a cozy, Michelin-starred spot or tacos in a trendy café.

title: Confessions of a repentant Wagner disinformation agent from the Central African Republic
summary: For eight months, Le Monde and nine international media partners, coordinated by Forbidden Stories, investigated the story of journalist Ephrem Ngonzo and the disinformation strategy implemented by Russia in the Central African Republic and later reproduced in West Africa.

title: 'We'll get that Hillsborough Law!': 35 years after disaster, wounds remain raw in Liverpool
summary: On April 15, 1989, Hillsborough Stadium became the scene of the deadliest disaster in British sporting history, with 96 Liverpool football fans killed in a stampede, and one dying from his injuries years later. Thirty-five years on, their families are campaigning for a law that would give victims of injustice more power against the government.

title: Philippe Jordan, the Orchestre National de France's new director: 'I'm particularly happy to return to Paris'
summary: The 50-year-old Swiss maestro has just been appointed to head the Parisian ensemble. The former music director of the Opéra National de Paris will succeed Cristian Macelaru in 2027.

title: How reading and stimulating brains is becoming accessible to all, for better or worse
summary: Brain implants, headbands and headphones fitted with electrodes: Brain reading and stimulation, once focused solely on therapeutic research, are now edging closer to general use, without much perspective or proof of effectiveness. The aim is no longer simply to treat and repair, but potentially to enhance brain function.

title: War in Ukraine: US criticized for authorizing supply of antipersonnel mines to Kyiv
summary: Washington justified its decision by citing a change of tactics on the part of the Russians. Volodymyr Zelensky considers these controversial weapons 'very important' to stopping Russian assaults.

title: Musk plans to slash US federal spending, possibly including from defense budget
summary: The Tesla CEO and entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy, appointed together by Trump to head a 'Department of Government Efficiency,' are taking aim at the usual Republican targets, from the Environmental Protection Agency to Planned Parenthood, while sharply criticizing the Pentagon.

title: French lawmakers approve creation of France-Palestine friendship group
summary: The Assemblée Nationale's bureau, which is dominated by the left, approved the move. The aim of friendship groups is to participate in the development of parliamentary diplomacy by creating links with foreign parliaments.

title: In closing arguments, Gisèle Pelicot's lawyers plea for end to 'rape culture'
summary: On Wednesday, Antoine Camus and Stéphane Babonneau somberly and with great sensitivity denounced the flaws in the defendants' arguments.

title: ICC issues arrest warrants for Netanyahu, Israeli defense minister and Hamas official
summary: The arrests target Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Yoav Gallant, as well as Hamas's military chief, Mohammed Deif.

title: Musée d'Orsay signs partnership with Louis Vuitton
summary: Le Monde has learned the flagship of the LVMH group is set to donate €20 million to the Parisian establishment.

title: Ukraine fires its first British Storm Shadow missiles into Russian territory
summary: The strike, using at least 12 missiles, targeted the Russian village of Marino on Wednesday afternoon.

title: Mali junta appoints general to replace sacked civilian prime minister
summary: Choguel Kokalla Maiga lost the job a day earlier following his criticism of the military leaders. New PM General Abdoulaye Maiga had until now served as the government's spokesman.

title: Jacques Labro, architect of Avoriaz ski resort, has died
summary: In the early 1960s, the young architect imagined a new kind of car-free resort, a far cry from the 'ski factories' that were springing up in the Alps at the time. He died on November 11 at the age of 89.
